flashcards.question: What is the scientific name for the domestic cat?
When and where did cat domestication occur?
flashcards.answer: In the Near East around 7500 BC

flashcards.question: What family does the domestic cat belong to?
What are cats valued by humans for?
flashcards.answer: Companionship and ability to kill vermin

flashcards.question: How are a cat's claws adapted?
flashcards.answer: Retractable claws adapted to killing small prey species

flashcards.content: Social species but solitary hunter and crepuscular predator

flashcards.question: What evidence indicates that cats were first domesticated in the Near East rather than Egypt?
flashcards.answer: Excavation near a Neolithic grave in Shillourokambos, Cyprus (7500-7200 BC) shows earliest indication of tamed African wildcat

flashcards.question: How many chromosomes does the domestic cat have?
When did development of cat breeds begin?

flashcards.content: 46 cm in head-to-body length, 23-25 cm in height, 30 cm long tails, 4-5 kg weight

flashcards.question: How many cervical vertebrae do cats have?
What allows cats to pass through spaces they can fit their head through?
flashcards.answer: Free-floating clavicle bones attached to the shoulder

flashcards.question: What is special about a cat's canine teeth?
flashcards.answer: Long canines for killing prey; can sever prey's spinal cord by stabbing between vertebrae

flashcards.question: Why do cats have better dental health than most humans?
flashcards.answer: Thicker protective layer of enamel, less damaging saliva, less retention of food particles, and diet mostly devoid of sugar

flashcards.question: What type of gait does a cat use when walking?
flashcards.answer: Pacing gait that alternates both legs together on each side

flashcards.question: How has the cat changed during domestication?
flashcards.answer: Only minor changes in anatomy and behavior; still capable of surviving in the wild

flashcards.content: 600 million cats worldwide, 400 million in Asia (58 million pet cats in China), 73.8 million in the US, 10.9 million in the UK

flashcards.definition: Derived from Old English 'catt', likely from Late Latin 'cattus' (6th century), possibly from an unidentified African language
A female cat (sometimes specifically unspayed cats in estrous cycle)
Terms for a group of cats

flashcards.content: Common ancestor 10-15 million years ago; evolutionary radiation 8.38-14.45 million years ago; genus Felis diverged 6-7 million years ago
Most cats have 5 claws on front paws, 4 on rear paws, with a dewclaw proximal to the others

flashcards.definition: Walking on toes with the bones of the feet making up the lower part of the visible leg

flashcards.content: Large eye sockets, powerful specialized jaw, narrowly spaced canine teeth adapted for small rodent prey

flashcards.prompt: Traits that pre-adapted cats for domestication
flashcards.content: Small size, social nature, obvious body language, love of play, high intelligence, grooming habits, and waste burial instinct
First evidence in Greece around 1200 BC; introduced by Greek, Phoenician, Carthaginian and Etruscan traders; reached Corsica and Sardinia by 1st century AD
Leopard cat was independently tamed in China around 5500 BC but left no trace in modern domestic cat populations
